Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: JUNO: Collaborative Research: ACTION: Applications Coordinating with Transport, IP, and Optical Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Today's Internet is significantly over-provisioned for a number of reasons, e.g., to absorb traffic bursts, to handle the extra (rerouted) load when failures occur, and for long-term traffic growth without frequent upgrades in the field. This overprovisioning adds significant capital costs to the Internet.

The ACTION project enables adaptation of the Internet to changing needs and demands by dynamically adjusting its "optical highway" capacities based on network resource utilization. The project name ACTION stands for "Applications Coordinate through Transport Interfaces with Optical Networks," implying that the capacity of the Internet optical highways is a time-adjustable commodity, which can be intelligently controlled by the applications via specially designed interfaces. For example, part of the optical spectrum can be freed on highways with low traffic volume and either reassigned to other highways where needed or switched off to conserve energy. Such flexible highways are achieved by combining WDM (Wavelength Division Multiplexing) Flexible Grid technology in the metro-core with DSCM (Digital Subcarrier Multiplexing) technology in the campus/access. The ACTION research activities will culminate in a final demonstration on the Japan Gigabit Network-extreme (JGN-X) test-bed.

The ACTION project will actively engage undergraduate students in Senior Thesis and Design Projects, recruit women and under-represented minorities by leveraging the UVA Center for Diversity in Engineering and the UTDallas long-standing relationship with CONACYT (National Council for Science and Technology of Mexico). Findings, documents, links to publications and software will be disseminated through a wiki-based Web site. All instructional materials developed will be made available at TeachEngineering.com.

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Texas at Dallas

POR.DRECONTENT:
Internet traffic volume Compound Annual Growth Rates (CAGRs) are in the 30-70% range and outpacing the technology advancements in networking. For a number of good reasons (e.g., handling traffic peaks, compensating for link failures, and TCP/IP inefficiency) network resources are significantly over-provisioned in today’s network architectures and it is quite common to see only 30%-40% resource utilization in deployed solutions. While new optical fibers can be laid, the costs of such deployment should be weighed against the costs of deploying solutions that enable network operations at higher utilization levels. For example, by properly leveraging the latest developments in optical coherent transmission systems, network architectures have now the potential to become more efficient, both in terms of spectral utilization of their fiber media and overall energy consumption, while still offering good reliability and stability properties. 
The scope of this project was to investigate possible architectural changes in the network that may be leveraged to overcome the main design inefficiencies of today’s network architectural solutions. The central enabler and common denominator of the PIs’ research agenda  ?  spanning from the optical physical to application layer  ?  is the notion that the link capacities between IP routers may be dynamically and carefully adjusted over time with the goal of increasing network resource utilization and best matching the application QoS requirements. IP links are created by reserving a portion of the fiber optical spectrum in the transport network, which can be implemented using Flex Grid Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) and Digital Subcarrier Multiplexing (DSCM) latest technologies. 
Contributions at the physical layer include: modeling of optical amplifier non-flat gain and noise figure through experimentation, modeling of wavelength selective switch reconfiguration time through experimentation, modeling of spectrum fragmentation in semi-flex grid transmission link, assessment of inherent unfair spectrum allocation in commonly used strategies and solutions to partially overcome the problem.
Contributions at the network layer include: cross layer allocation strategies for jointly determining wavelength assignment and signal power equalization across the spectrum for improved circuit optical signal-to-noise ratio, solutions for scheduling resource (end-to-end optical circuits) reservation to mitigate the adverse effect of wavelength selective switch reconfiguration time.
Contributions at the application layer include: a series of experiments that resulted from a coordinated effort across a number of participating organizations, i.e., Keio University, The University of Texas at Dallas, NICT, Southwest Research Institute (SwRI), KDDI R&D Labs, NTT Communications, Redhat, Fujitsu, IXIA communications, OA Laboratory, Toyo Corporation, and Mitsubishi Electric. The experimental work had a double objective. The first objective was to prove that in Advanced Manufacturing (and other similar fields), it is possible to achieve a virtually geographically unconstrained remote control of industrial robots. In one of the demonstrations, an industrial robot performed a flat surface blending of a metal piece (in San Antonio, Texas) while the application was being controlled by a Cloud server (in Dallas, Texas) under the supervision of a remote operator (in Tokyo, Japan). The second objective was to demonstrate the advantage of making use of an SDN-based network infrastructure consisting of 3 interconnected optical networks and one Edge compute facility. Through the SDN controller, it was possible to reserve compute resources at the Edge (not too far from the robot), while still performing other more demanding computational tasks in the Cloud (and across the Pacific Ocean).  The combined and well-orchestrated use of Edge and Cloud compute resources allowed the blending application to be carried out in a timely manner, thus circumventing well-known drawbacks caused by significant network round trip times. 
This series of experiments was made possible by the collaborative environment created by this JUNO funded project. The industrial robot and the robot application software were provided by two research teams in the United States. The SDN-based orchestration of multiple optical networks and Edge compute resources was provided by a number of teams operating in Japan. The geographical distance between the two groups of key players made it possible to run the experiment across a wide network with significant latency (about 135ms of network round trip time).
In terms of broader impact, the results of this project can be used to improve fiber optics spectrum utilization and deliver improved network capacity at the higher layers of the protocol stack. In addition, demonstrating the feasibility of advanced manufacturing distributed applications paves the way to a number of possible developments in this field. For example, the production floor can be free of high performance computing equipment by instead making use of remote Edge and Cloud computing resources.
